description:
Miscellaneous financial and economic data from the during the U.S. Civil War

This is by no means a complete collection of available data, but consists of some datasets that I found or collected for my own research.
title: Civil War (US) Era Financial Market Data

resources.description:
Daily price of greenbacks in gold in New York (1862-1879)
The price of greenbacks comes from Mitchel (1908), which was put in machine format by Willard et. al. and made available on http://eh.net/databases/greenback/. The data here correct several mistakes in that data.

resources.description: Interest rates in New York Money Market, 1860-1865 average rates per month for call loans

New York market holidays (1860-1879)

The list of holidays largely comes from the days Mitchell (1908). It is extended back to 1860. During this era, the market appears to have been open on Saturdays, and the only regularly observed holidays were Christmas, New Years, Independence Day and sometimes Thanksgiving (after 1862).

resources.description: Interest rates in New York Money Market, 1860-1865, average rates per year

Price data for U.S. government and state bonds 1855-1865.

These data appear in tables in the *Notes on the Money Market* section 
of the *Bankers' Magazine* for volumes 10-19. The description of the tables
noted that these were "the highest cash prices offered ... for the Government 
and leading state securities in the market." `June 22, 1864 <http://books.google.com/books?id=lGAmAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA78>`__.

The prices appear are nominal (not gold) dollars, and were dirty prices for the most part.

resources.description:
Price data for U.S. bonds and notes from the Merchants Magazine, 1862-1865

These data appear in tables entitled "Prices United States Paper" appearing
in the section "Commercial Chronicle and Review" of the *Merchants' Magazine
and Commercial Review*. 

The Merhcants' Magazine only began quoting prices of US paper in 1862.
